COMMENTS
Auction offerings totalled 7.0 M/Kgs this week, a significantly higher volume from the 5.1 M/Kgs on offer the previous week. This is the highest volume on offer since Sale No. 20 of 23/24 May 2023. There was fair demand.
Ex-Estate offerings too recorded an increase over last and totalled 1.14 M/Kgs. There was less demand with overall quality showing a further decline.
Best Western BOP/BOPF's - A selection of better teas were firm to dearer by Rs. 20 per kg, whilst the others declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg. BOP/BOPF's in the Below Best category too were easier by Rs. 40-60 per kg, whilst teas at the lower end declined further. Nuwara Eliya BOP/BOPF's were mostly unsold due to a lack of suitable bids. Uva/Uda Pussellawa BOP/BOPF's - A few Select Best invoices sold well following special inquiry, whilst the others and teas at the bottom declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more.
High Grown CTC teas - BP1's had hardly any offerings. Better PF1's declined by approximately Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others sold around last levels. Medium Grown BP1's - Better teas continued to sell well, whilst the others were mostly lower. PF1's were mostly unsold and where sold, were Rs. 20-40 per kg lower. Corresponding Low Grown varieties - BP1's gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst PF1's declined by a similar margin.
Low Growns comprised of 2.9 M/Kgs.  All categories met with fair demand.
In the Leafy and Semi-Leafy catalogues, well-made BOP1's were firm to dearer, whilst the balance together with the bolder varieties were easier.  OP1's in general were firm, whilst OP's were easier. Select Best OPA's recorded a noticeable decline, whilst the Best and Below Best varieties too were easier to a lesser extent. Teas at the lower end maintained at last levels. Select Best PEK's appreciated, whilst the balance were lower. However, teas at the bottom sold around last levels. PEK1's, in general, were firm to dearer.
In the Tippy catalogue, FBOP's were maintained at last levels, whilst the bolder varieties were irregular following quality. FBOPF1's, in general, were firm.
In the Premium catalogue, Very Tippy teas met with good demand and were firm, whilst the Best together with Below Best and cleaner teas at the bottom sold at last levels. Balance were irregular following quality.
SRI LANKA TEA PRODUCTION - APRIL 2025
APRIL 2025/2024/2023
*
Sri Lanka Tea Production
for the month of April 2025 totalled 26.39 M/Kgs, showing an increase of 4.93 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 21.46 M/Kgs of April 2024. All elevations record an increase, in comparison with the corresponding month of 2024.
* Compared to 25.24 M/Kgs of April 2023, the corresponding month in the year 2025 shows an increase of 1.15 M/Kgs (Refer table below).
JANUARY-APRIL 2025/2024/2023
* January-April 2025 cumulative production totalled 88.38 M/Kgs, recording an increase of 8.65 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 79.73 M/Kgs of January-April 2024. All elevations show an increase in comparison with the corresponding period of 2024.
* Compared to 84.75 M/Kgs of January-April 2023, cumulative production of 2025 shows an increase of 3.63 M/Kgs. On a cumulative basis, the High and Mid Grown elevations recorded increases, whilst the Low Grown elevation and Green Tea segment have shown negative variances when compared with the same period in the year 2023 (Refer table below).
(Refer statistical details on Page No. 12)
SRI LANKA TEA EXPORTS - APRIL 2025
Key Highlights:
* Sri Lanka Tea Exports for the month was recorded at 18.20 M/Kgs - (Increase of 1.82 M/Kgs YoY)
*
Cumulative Exports totalled 81.41 M/Kgs (Increase of 2.71 M/Kgs YoY) in comparison with January-April 2024 total of 78.70 M/Kgs
*
F.O.B Value for the month recorded Rs. 1,760.31 (USD 5.90), recording an increase of Rs. 14.86 (Gain of USD 0.07) against April 2024. Cumulative FOB Value declined by Rs. 28.75 in comparison with the corresponding period of 2024, whilst the to date USD earnings continued to show an overall improvement in all categories
* Iraq continues to maintain the top position amongst leading importer countries of Ceylon Tea for the year, whilst Libya makes significant improvement to secure 2
nd
place edging over Russia
April 2025/2024
* Tea Exports for the month of April 2025 totalled 18.20 M/Kgs, showing an increase of 1.82 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 16.38 M/Kgs of April 2024. All categories have recorded positive variances, except for the Tea in Bulk category. FOB value in April 2025 was recorded at Rs. 1,760.31, an increase of Rs. 14.86 YoY compared to Rs. 1,745.45 of April 2024. In USD terms, however, the month of April witnessed an increase of USD 0.07 in comparison with the corresponding period in the year 2024 (Refer table below).
JANUARY-APRIL 2025/2024
* January-April 2025 cumulative exports totalled 81.41 M/Kgs, recording a positive variance of 2.71 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 78.70 M/Kgs of January-April 2024. Tea Packets, Tea Bags and Instant Tea segments have recorded positive variances, whilst the Tea in Bulk and Green Tea categories witnessed a decline against the same period of the previous year.
* FOB value for the period stood at Rs. 1,743.61, a decrease of Rs. 28.75 (increase of USD 0.15) vis-à-vis Rs. 1,772.36 of January-April 2024.
* All categories except for Instant Tea recorded negative variances in LKR terms in FOB value, whilst gains were recorded in USD terms in all categories when compared to the corresponding period in 2024 (Refer table below).
Iraq ranks at No. 01 amongst major importers of Ceylon Tea with a total of 11.52 M/Kgs, an increase of 13% YoY in January-April 2025 against the previous year's 10.23 M/Kgs. Libya ranks in 2
nd
Place with 7.61 M/Kgs, an improvement of 353% surpassing Russia at 3
rd
place who has witnessed a significant decline of 9% YoY with 7.50 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 8.27 M/Kgs recorded in 2024. The U.A.E is place at No. 4 with 5.52 M/Kgs (35% decrease YoY) followed by Türkiye 4.29 M/Kgs (19% decrease YoY), Iran 4.09 M/Kgs (1% decrease YoY). Chile has secured 7
th
position with 3.77 M/Kgs edging over China 3.15 M/Kgs, Saudi Arabia 2.89 M/Kgs followed by Germany at 2.73 M/Kgs for January-April 2025.
(Refer statistical details on Page Nos. 9 and 10)

MARKET
Less demand
HIGH GROWN TEAS
BOP
Best Western's - A selection of clean leaf invoices sold around last week's closing levels, whilst the others declined by Rs. 40-50 per kg. Teas in the Below Best category, where quality was maintained, gained by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others declined by a similar margin and more. Teas at the lower end were easier by Rs. 40-60 per kg. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold due to a lack of suitable bids. Uda Pussellawa's - A few select Best gained considerably following special inquiry, whilst the others declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more. Uva's - A few invoices in the Best category gained considerably following special inquiry, whilst the others declined by Rs. 40-50 per kg.
BOPF
A selection of clean leaf coloury teas in the Best and Below Best categories were firm and irregularly dearer by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others declined by Rs. 50 per kg. Teas at the lower end which commenced Rs. 40-60 per kg lower, declined further towards the close. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold due to a lack of suitable bids. Uda Pussellawa's - Better teas declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more, whilst the others declined to a lesser extent. Uva's - A few invoices sold around last levels following special inquiry, whilst the others declined by Rs. 40 per kg and more.
OP/OPA
Well-made varieties declined by Rs. 50-70 per kg, whilst the others and poorer sorts were firm to easier by Rs. 20 per kg.
PEKOE/PEKOE1
Flavoury PEK's were easier by Rs. 60-100 per kg. Orthodox Leafy PEK's were firm to dearer by Rs. 20-40 per kg. Best PEK1's were firm to easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others decline by Rs. 60-100 per kg. A few Best Rotovane PEK's sold at last levels following quality/special inquiry, whilst the balance declined by Rs. 50 per kg and more. Others and poorer sorts declined further following quality.
FBOP/FBOPF1
Select Best flavoury FBOP's were firm to irregularly dearer by Rs. 40-60 per kg selectively. Better Orthodox FBOP's were dearer by Rs. 20 per kg, whilst the FBOPF1's were firm to irregularly easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more at times. Below Best FBOP/FBOPF1's were easier by Rs. 30-50 per kg, whilst the teas at the lower end were easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg.

CROP AND WEATHER
For the period 13 - 19 May 2025
Western/Nuwara Eliya Regions
Bright mornings and evening showers were reported in the Western and Nuwara Eliya regions. The Department of Meteorology expects heavy showers in both regions in the week ahead.
Uva/Uda Pussellawa Regions
The Uva and Uda Pussellawa regions reported bright mornings and occasional evening showers throughout the week. According to the Department of Meteorology, showers are expected  in both regions in the week ahead.
Low Growns
The Low Grown Region reported rainy weather throughout the week. Fairly heavy showers are expected in the Low Grown Region in the week ahead according to the Department of Meteorology.
Crop Intake
The crop intake was maintained in
the
Western Medium, Nuwara Eliya, Uva, Uda Pussellawa and Low Grown regions, whilst the Western High Region reported a decrease.

SALE OF - 12TH & 13TH MAY 2025 (SALE NO. 19)
Demand remained fair at irregular rates for the 188,879 packages (12,933,401.00 kilos) available in the market; 39.63% remained unsold.
MARKETS
Pakistan Packers showed more activity while Yemen, other Middle Eastern countries, Kazakhstan and other CIS states were strong and dominant. Bazaar showed less interest while Afghanistan lent some support. UK maintained enquiry with Egyptian Packers more active but at lower rates. Russia and South Sudan showed less participation with Sudan absent. Local Packers reduced interest while Somalia maintained support at the lower end of the market.

BANGLADESH AUCTION
SALE OF - 19TH MAY 2025 (SALE NO. 03)
CTC LEAF: 23,903 packages of tea on offer met with a better demand.
BROKENS/FANNINGS: Well made good liquoring varieties continued to meet with a strong demand at firm to slightly dearer rates following competition and these could be quoted between Tk.270/- and Tk.300/-. Below best varieties were a good market and were about steady in line with quality selling between Tk.230/- and Tk.250/-. All others met with a little more demand at firm to slightly easier rates and these could be quoted between Tk.200/- and Tk.220/-. BLF teas sold fairly well and sold between Tk.160/- and Tk.220/-.
DUST: 4,426 packages of tea on offer met with quite a good demand. Good liquoring Dusts sold well at slightly easier rates. Their Mediums sold irregularly following quality. Plain/BLF Dust met with an improved demand and were fully firm to slightly dearer. Blenders lent good support with fair interest from the Loose tea buyers.
COMMENTS: There was a little more demand this week from all sections of the market. The best varieties continued to sell at firm to slightly dearer rates in line with quality. Blenders again lent strong support with Loose tea buyers operating more actively.
Dusts sold well.

JAKARTA AUCTION
SALE OF - 10TH MAY 2025 (SALE NO. 19)
CTC LEAF
DEMAND: - Good demand for the best category, others met with reduced demand with easier price levels and very erratic especially on the better medium and medium category teas.
MARKET: - The total CTC leaf teas sold this week was 67.49 %(1,180,143.47kgs) of the total offering of 1,748,673.72Kgs.
BEST:- Best liquoring teas on offer with demand continuing to persist from the local and regional buyers with prices fluctuating irregularly closely following quality.Local and Regional packagers continued to be fairly active.
GOOD:- Larger and medium broken sold barely steady to easier, smaller broken eased by Rs 2 to 6 especially on the top end. Very limited fanning grade was on offer. Regional packagers, upcountry buyers were choosy and more price sensitive.
BETTER MEDIUM & MEDIUM:- Better medium and medium category, all sorts saw a downward trend with prices declining between Rs 2 to 5. However, the prices continued to show no disparity between both the categories especially on the medium and smaller broken grades. Major blenders and Western India Packateers were fairly active. Selective buying was seen from the upcountry and local buyers. Exporters were fairly active on on cleaner, blacker fanning. Larger broken continue to meet with selective buying from exporters and larger percentage of teas remain unsold.
PLAINERS:- Further reduced demand with prices declining in the range of Rs 4 to 6 with bulk of teas remaining unsold in this segment. Limited buying from exporters. Major blenders were very choosy and internal buyers were selective along with the upcountry buyers but at substantially easier prices.
BUYING PATTERN: - The major blenders off take was 57.05% of the total CTC leaf sold.
ORTHODOX LEAF
DEMAND: - Good demand.
MARKET: - Well made clean high grown whole leaf sold steady to easier following quality. Other category were ruling barely stedy to easier market following quality. Broken and fanning grades were barely steady to easier.
BUYING PATTERN: - Exporters & up country buyers continued to be fairly active closely following quality.
CTC DUST
DEMAND: - Fair demand.
MARKET: - CTC dust offer this week was at 478,678.54Kgs of which 379,778.64kgs were sold (79.34%).
Best teas continue to meet with good demand and prices were irregular and easier on all sorts closely following quality. Good category teas were fully firm to occasionally dearer. Better medium & medium teas were barely steady to easier by Rs 1 to 2. Plainer teas were steady at last prices.
BUYING PATTERN: - Major blenders were fairly active. Regional and local packeteers were selective along with the Up country and the local buyers . Exporters were fairly active on the bolder dust especially on cleaner and blacker sorts.
ORTHODOX DUST
DEMAND: - Good demand.
MARKET: - Primary dusts sold at irregular and easier levels following quality, secondaries sold at irregular levels.
BUYING PATTERN: - Regional & local packateers were fairly active on primary dusts. Exporters were selective on the secondary dusts.
Courtesy - J.Thomas & Co. Pvt. Ltd
